did.head: DESCRIPTIVE SUMMARY

persname.normal: [give the MARC presentation of creator here, i.e., surname first; include dates]

did.repository: Division of Rare and Manuscript Collections, Cornell University Library
did.abstract: Two scrapbooks and one photograph album kept by Archibald R. Ward from 1910-1914, documenting his work in the Philippines, primarily relating to cattle diseases such as rinderpest and contagious bovine pleuropneumonia. Also, two laboratory notebooks kept by Ward as a student at Cornell University, one for a course in General Chemistry (1893-1894) and one for a course in Chemistry: Qualitative Analysis (circa 1895).

bioghist.head: BIOGRAPHICAL NOTE
bioghist.p: Archibald Robinson Ward received his DVM from the New York State College of Veterinary Medicine in 1901. He was the first veterinarian to be appointed at the University of California, Berkeley. He also spent several years in the Philippines as the country's chief veterinarian, a position appointed by the United States Department of Insular Affairs. His primary purpose there was to rid the nation's cattle of several contagious diseases, such as rinderpest and contagious bovine pleuropneumonia. He later became Dean of the Veterinary College at the University of the Philippines, Manilla.

scopecontent.head: COLLECTION DESCRIPTION
scopecontent.p: Two scrapbooks and one photograph album kept by Archibald R. Ward from 1910-1914, documenting his work in the Philippines, primarilly relating to cattle diseases such as rinderpest and contagious bovine pleuropneumonia. The scrapbooks are labeled "Scrapbook Number 3" and "Scrapbook Number 4." An inscription in Scrapbook No. 3 indicates that the first two volumes were given to the Society of American Bacteriologists.
Also, two laboratory notebooks kept by Ward as a student at Cornell University, one for a course in General Chemistry (1893-1894) and one for a course in Chemistry: Qualitative Analysis (circa 1895).

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions:
accessrestrict.p: Both scrapbooks are extremely brittle. Photocopying may be prohibited.

prefercite.head: Cite As:
prefercite.p: Archibald R. Ward Papers, #6596. Division of Rare and Manuscript Collections, Cornell University Library.

custodhist.head: HISTORY OF OWNERSHIP
custodhist.p: Donated to the Flower Veterinary Library by Dr. Ward in 1944.

acqinfo.head: PROVENANCE
acqinfo.p: Transfered to the Division of Rare and Manuscript Collections in 2004
